newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Shenzhen B index ends lower on profit-taking.
newsitem.headline: Shenzhen B index ends lower on profit-taking.

text.p: Shenzhen's B shares zig-zagged to a lower close on Tuesday as investors took profits from gains earlier in the session but the market mood remained positive, analysts said.

The B index edged down 0.07 points or 0.04 percent to end the day at 162.50 points. Turnover was a thin HK$73.3 million compared with HK$88.4 million last Thursday before the market closed in line with Hong Kong's Easter holiday.
"Investors took profits after the B index went up in the morning on optimism over China's economic prospects," an analyst at China Guotai Securities said.
China's State Statistical Bureau said China's economy would grow by 10 percent in 1997 with the inflation rate around five percent, according to Monday's Shenzhen-based Securities Times.
"Although the index ended lower, investors are optimistic," the Guotai analyst said.
Traders said the absence of a market clampdown widely rumoured last month had also buoyed the market mood.
"No regulatory news is good news in the short term," a trader at Central-South Securities said.
Analysts said investors were reluctant to place large orders ahead of the April 30 deadline for listed companies to publish their 1996 annual reports.
Only three out of 44 B share companies listed in Shenzhen have so far made their results public.
Shenzhen Tellus Machinery & Electronics Co Ltd was the worst performer and hit its 10 percent limit-down at HK$3.38 on volume of 690,000 shares.
The B share market resumed trading on Tuesday after closing for the past two sessions in line with Hong Kong's Easter holiday.

However, some trading took place on Friday morning due to what the Shenzhen stock exchange said was a technical error, and the transactions were carried over to Tuesday, a stock exchange statement said.
The A share index gained 1.28 points or 0.28 percent to 459.76 points on turnover of 10.1 billion yuan against Monday's 10.8 billion yuan.
